summary: caveolae are involved in diverse cellular functions such as signal transduction, cholesterol homeostasis, endo- and transcytosis. their occurrence in epithelium of the airways may be expected but has not yet been examined. cav-1-immunoreactivity and caveolae were absent in cav-1-deficient mice. caveolae are integral membrane components in basal and ciliated epithelial cells. caveolae are omega-shaped invaginations of the plasma membrane measuring 50 to 100 nm in diameter. a role of these proteins for the development cycle of Chlamydiae is discussed. the human coronavirus 229E is known to induce respiratory tract infections. the presence of caveolins, their interaction, and the presence of caveolae in tracheal and bronchial epithelial cells have not yet been determined. a selective association of cav-2 but not cav-1 was described with Chlamydia pneumoniae. it is likely that both proteins can have divergent functions during infectious processes. we therefore examined the expression of caveolae and caveolins in bronchial and tracheal epithelium.
